topic.title: HPE Helion Development Platform 2.0: ALS Cluster Management Tool Reference

body.p: The ALS command-line interface client (cf-mgmt.exe) provides an option for executing commands that construct, manage, update, or delete ALS clusters. Use the command line when the Horizon management console is unavailable or when direct access is preferred. The system where cf-mgmt is installed requires 1) access to the OpenStack public endpoint and 2) access to port 80 on the tenant network where the target ALS cluster is created.

li.xref: Add a Role to an Existing Cluster
Remove a Role from an Existing Cluster
Add a Service to an Existing Cluster
Remove a Service from an Existing Cluster

section.title: Configuration Values
section.p: There are three ways to pass configuration values into ALS:

ul.li: Direct entry through the cf-mgmt tool

section.title: Configuration Files
section.p: ALS maintains separate configuration files, so configuration values must be included in the appropriate file.When creating clusters that support Keystone v3, you will need to modify the configuration file first.
One configuration file contains the values for the global variables. The global configuration file is located in the home directory and is named cf-mgmt.yml.

ul.li: Global level commands create, delete, and add entire clusters.
Global level configurations manage tenants, users, versions, and other system information on single or multiple clusters.

section.p: The other configuration files, specified by the --load option, includes the values that should be passed as arguments to a specific command.

section.title: Global Options
section.p: These variables affect the entire cluster; they are global in scope. These environment variables are configured to work with the OpenStack Python tools to enable faster integration. If you are using Keystone v3 authentication, additional parameters are required.

row.entry: Enables additional debug information. Valid options are: general, cpi, shell, kato, timing, all
Simulate the command with provided flags.
Yes, if tenant-id is not defined. Keystone v2 only.
Yes, if tenant-name is not defined. Keystone v2 only.
The default location for the configuration file is the user home directory.
Enter a new file path to change the location of the configuration file.
Displays the version of the client.

section.p: The following parameters are required if you are using Keystone v3 authentication. They are not required for Keystone v2.

row.entry: Yes, if using Keystone v3 authentication.
Yes, if using Keystone v3 authentication.
Yes, if using Keystone v3 authentication.
Yes, if using Keystone v3 authentication.
Yes, if using Keystone v3 authentication.
Yes, if using Keystone v3 authentication.
Yes, if using Keystone v3 authentication.
Yes, if using Keystone v3 authentication.
Yes, if using Keystone v3 authentication.

section.title: Debugging
section.p: Syntax: --debug [option] [option]
This command provides debug information and can be very helpful when creating clusters.
The options are general, cpi, shell, kato, timing, all.
CPI stands for Cloud Provider Instance and will return information on HPE Helion OpenStack.
Example: cf-mgmt --debug all cc

section.title: Cluster Commands
section.p: These commands are available from the command line interface.

p.note: When executing any command for the first time, include the --dry-run option. This will help detect potential configuration or environmental issues before making any actual changes.

row.entry: Add services to an existing cluster.
Add node of the specified role to an existing cluster.
Remove services from an existing cluster.
Remove node of the specified role from an existing cluster.
Update to the most recent version of cf-mgmt
Displays a list of available commands or help for a command.

section.title: Create a Cluster
section.p: This command creates a cluster. (create-cluster).

When creating clusters that support Keystone v3, you will need to modify the configuration file first.
For more information on DNS suffix requirements, see the full configuration documentation.For help with this command within the command-line interface, enter

Prefix to affix to cluster instance names.

Fixed Floating IP for the core machine. A Floating IP is one that is publicly available. When assigned to a machine, it becomes a Fixed IP.

Required only if constructor-image-name is undefined. Optional if constructor-image-name is defined.
Flavor name for the constructor server
Duration to wait for the constructor virtual machine to come up. The default is 10 minutes.
Keep the constructor virtual machine up and running after command completion.
Do not rollback in the event of a failure.

section.title: Delete a Cluster
section.p: This command deletes a cluster (delete-cluster).

section.title: Use Syntax

Required only if constructor-image-id is undefined. Optional if constructor-image-id is defined.
ID of the image of the constructor server
Required only if constructor-image-name is undefined. Optional if constructor-image-name is defined.
Flavor name of the constructor server
Maximum time to wait for cluster deletion to occur. Default wait time is 4 minutes.
Name of the subnet for the Constructor VM, the cluster created by create-cluster and the DEA nodes added by add-role dea.

section.title: List Clusters
section.p: Lists all clusters that exist on a single tenant. (list-clusters)
section.title: Use Syntax
section.p: For help with this command within the command-line interface, enter

section.title: Show Details
section.p: Displays detailed information about the target cluster. (show-cluster)
For help with this command within the command-line interface, enter

row.entry: Prefix to affix to cluster instance names.
Shows a list of commands or help for one command.

section.title: Add Roles to an Existing Cluster
section.p: Options can be passed when adding roles to an existing cluster (add-role dea).

p.note: Adding a role will create one or more additional nodes in the cluster as part of the process.

section.title: Use Syntax
section.p: For help with this command within the command-line interface, enter

row.entry: Add DEA nodes to an existing cluster.

Save flag values to the specified file

Number of nodes in the cluster
Name of the image of the constructor server.
Required only if seed-node-image-id is undefined. Optional if seed-node-image-id is defined.
Name of the image of the constructor server.
Required only if seed-node-image-name is undefined. Optional if seed-node-image-name is defined.
Flavor name of the instance in the cluster.
The name of the key pair on instances
Maximum time to wait for addition of node or service to cluster; defaults to an infinite wait.
Flavor name reference to use when creating a constructor server
Name of the subnet for the Constructor VM, the cluster created by create-cluster and the DEA nodes added by add-role dea.
Deprecated in favor of network-name. Avoid use.
ID of the subnet for the Constructor VM, the cluster created by create-cluster and the DEA nodes added by add-role dea.
Deprecated in favor of network-id. Avoid use.
ID of the network for the created nodes

Duration to wait for the constructor machine to come up. Default is 10 minutes.
Availability zone for the created node.
Stack indicates the platform to use when adding DEAs. Valid values are lucid64 or win2012r2. Default is lucid64

section.title: Update the cf-mgmt Tool
section.p: This command checks for and downloads the latest version of the cf-mgmt.exe tool.
There are no arguments for this command. Passing the Help option will generate an empty list.

row.entry: Shows a list of commands or help for one command.

section.title: Remove Services from an Existing Cluster
section.p: This command removes services from an existing cluster (add-service). Private keys with passcodes are not supported by the cf-mgmt tool. Attempting to run (for example):cf-mgmt remove-service mysql --private-key foo.pemwill result in the error foo.pem does not contain a valid PKCS1 private key. To work around this, ssh in to the node itself, run kato node detach, and then delete the service using one of the OpenStack tools: the nova client, openstack client, or the Horizon UI.

section.title: Use Syntax
section.p: For help with each subcommand, enter

section.title: Remove Roles From an Existing Cluster
section.note: Private keys with passcodes are not supported by the cf-mgmt tool. Attempting to run (for example):cf-mgmt remove-role dea --private-key foo.pemwill result in the error foo.pem does not contain a valid PKCS1 private key. To work around this, ssh in to the node itself, run kato node detach, and then delete the role using one of the OpenStack tools: the nova client, openstack client, or the Horizon UI.

section.p: For help with this command within the command-line interface, enter

Flavor name reference to use when creating a constructor server
ID of the network for the created nodes
Name of the network for the created nodes
Name of the external network for the public created nodes.
ID of the external network for the public created nodes.
Duration to wait for the constructor machine to come up. Default is 10 minutes.
Keep the constructor VM up and running after command completion.
The private key file needed to connect to cluster nodes.
The instance number of the role to be removed from the cluster.
Stack indicates the platform to use when adding DEAs. Valid values are lucid64 or win2012r2. Default is lucid64
